results.title: Balinese surfer 2: wave of change [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Lucky Country Productions, ABC-TV (Australia), Bill Leimbach and Richard Flax
results.brief_description: In 1978, producer/director Bill Leimbach visited the Indonesian island of Bali and filmed a group of young Balinese boys who had discovered the art of surfing. This is the sequel to that film “Balinese surfer” as Bill and his production team revisit the original group, now all aged in their 40s, 25 years later. We follow their individual stories, the direction life has taken them, and how most of them still take time out to surf. Through personal narratives, intercut with footage from the original film, these Balinese men all express their concern for the environment, particularly with the enormous increase in tourism during the 80s and 90s. Their priority issues are with maintaining the supply of fresh water, and preventing sewage run-off into the ocean, reef bombing, and toxic gases from burning plastic. Bali is renowned for having some of the best waves in the world and through a program of surfing contests (attracting the international media), surfing magazines and an organization called Wave of Change, the focus is now on the next generation, who also surf, to be environmental ambassadors and promote the message for preservation of the marine environment and a policy of sustainable development in Bali and throughout the Indonesian islands. Narration - John Sheerin; Director of Photography - Simon Manzie.

results.title: Balinese surfer
results.creator_credit: Survival Films, Tony Dutton and Bill Leimbach
results.brief_description: Shows how the younger generation on the island of Bali have overcome the traditional Balinese fear of the sea to excel in the sport of surfing. Also explains the Balinese attitude to religion and how it is absorbed into every facet of their lives, especially their art and dancing.

results.title: Balinese interlude
results.brief_description: A travelogue on Bali, one of the 7,000 islands that make up the land mass of Indonesia. We visit a fishing village, see examples and areas showing the ingenious terrace cultivation of rice. Many of the entertainments shown are based on Hindu-Balinese religious beliefs which also play a large part in the everyday life of villagers.

results.title: Bali today
results.brief_description: Illustrates life on the small volcanic island of Bali in Indonesia. Emphasises the role of the Brahmin religion in everyday life, with scenes of the rice harvest, colourful dance ceremonies, and flower offerings to the gods. Examples of weaving and mask-making illustrates Balinese art. No other credits available.

results.title: Balance 1950
results.brief_description: Animated drawings showing the balance sheet of Imperial Chemical Industries for 1950. Vivacious little “match stick” men, aided by ever active “Pound” and other devices perform against a backdrop of graphs and ledgers. An interesting example of simplified animation technique in which an unpopular subject is treated in an entertaining way.

results.title: Balada O Podravini
results.brief_description: A big, featherless bird helps us discover Podravina and its inhabitants. It is autumn, the crops are in, and we are invited to a country fair and a funeral. We understand how the peasants approach life and the world around them through this animated film.
